Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the step-parent should purchase it
Situation2: The weekly group meditation meets for an hour today, and I am the leader of the session.
Story: I stare at the clock, feeling the weight of the day pressing in. My stepson’s hopeful eyes linger in my mind—he’s been waiting all week for the Nintendo I promised. He’s been counting down, and I know how much it means to him, especially after the move and all the changes. But the cost is steep, and I’ve been watching our budget closely, trying to keep us afloat. At the same time, tonight is the weekly meditation group. I’m the leader, and everyone counts on me to guide the session, to be calm and present, to embody the mindfulness I teach. I can’t be late, and I can’t be distracted. But my mind is anything but calm. I feel torn—between the promise I made to my stepson and the commitment I made to my sangha, between the material needs of my family and the spiritual practice that grounds me. My heart aches with the pressure, and I close my eyes, searching for a breath of clarity, knowing I can’t be in two places at once.
